message: It was such an honor to take the oath of office for another term representing the people of the 4th Congressional District and the state of Alabama. It was also a special blessing to have my daughter and son join me on the House floor as I took the oath. Now the hard part begins. I will work with my Republican colleagues, and soon-to-be President Trump, to see that a new agenda for the American people is our top priority.
NA
Congressman Byrne, Congressman Palmer and myself are watching the game tonight with some of our Clemson supporting colleagues from South Carolina. Roll Tide!

According to a report, the 4th Congressional District of Alabama voted for Donald Trump and Mike Pence by a wider margin than any other district in the country.  I'm proud to be in Congress working to implement Mr. Trump's plan to revitalize our country.  I'm also excited that in just a little more than a week, Donald Trump and Mike Pence will be officially sworn in as our new President and Vice President.
Senator Sessions did a great job today. He showed the rest of the country what Alabama already knows, that he will make a great United States Attorney General.

Before it even became law, Americans voiced their concern and displeasure with Obamacare.  The law, passed in 2010 without a single Republican vote, has never been favored by a majority of Americans.  Today I joined my Republican colleagues in voting for the first step to repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act.  We can do better than Obamacare and we will. My Republican colleagues and I are working on a plan that will lower the average family’s healthcare premium by $2500 per year.  Today’s vote was the first step in making healthcare affordable again.

It was an honor to be at the dedication today of the new Red Mill Bridge in Marshall County.  This project had been decades in the making and many people had been hurt or killed on the old single lane bridges.  I also spoke with Donald Nixon, whose 17-year-old daughter died at the old bridge back in 2006.
NA
I enjoyed getting to give a Washington update this morning to the Cullman Chamber of Commerce.   I was also glad to meet with many of the county's mayors as well.

It was a lot of fun meeting with everyone who came by the office in Washington today to get their inauguration tickets.  I hope and pray that you all have a safe and wonderful time at the ceremony tomorrow as we welcome our 45th President.
Congratulations President Trump and Vice President Pence.  You took the oath at noon, but it is no doubt morning again in America.

This afternoon I spoke in the House of Representatives to express my support for a permanent ban on taxpayer funded abortions.  As I have said before, no argument in support of abortion can overcome one absolute truth: abortion stops an innocent human heartbeat.  We should not be in the business of using tax dollars to help end innocent life.
It was an honor to speak this afternoon with British Prime Minister Theresa May. Our special relationship with the United Kingdom is only going to become stronger in the coming years.
This clip is from the coverage of the protests in Philadelphia yesterday.  As long as people on the two coasts have this mind set, they will never win another Presidential election.
NA

Quite frankly, I think it is commonsense for additional vetting to occur for the countries that are home to ISIS and AL Qaeda. The fact that some in DC are lost in the political correctness of this is not that surprising.  This order is clearly not about banning Muslims, as only seven Muslim countries are on the list. There are currently more than 50 countries that are predominantly Muslim around the world. Therefore, more than 40 countries have no such restrictions.

I am humbled to be involved with the National Prayer Breakfast that emphasizes the importance of religious faith in our country.  I'm also honored to have President Trump attend, continuing a tradition that began with President Eisenhower.

I was sad to hear of former Alabama Speaker Tom Drake’s passing.  His career as a wrestler made him known throughout the country.  But he will also be remembered for the way he fought for the common man in Montgomery.  His family is in my prayers.

It was a treat and honor for my daughter Mary Elliott and me to meet with Mr. Jim Downing at yesterday's prayer breakfast.  He is 103 and one of few remaining survivors of the Pearl Harbor attack.  Thank you Mr. Downing for the service you gave to our country.
NA

Mary Elliott and I got to meet with President Trump last night after his speech.  I told him what a great speech it was and how I felt it would be well received.  And this morning, it appears that even frequent critics of the President are praising his address to Congress.

Here is the statement I released today concerning the allegations against Attorney General Jeff Sessions:  “The unsubstantiated allegations about Russian coordination are becoming almost like the ‘birther’ issue of the Democratic party,” said Robert Aderholt.“  It is not at all unusual for members of Congress to speak with ambassadors from other countries on an almost weekly basis.  The fact of the matter is that Jeff Sessions is an American patriot who would not do anything to jeopardize the sanctity and security of the country he not only has served for decades, but a country he deeply loves.� �     “These allegations are nothing more than a partisan smoke screen to detract from the fact Donald Trump won the election fair and square.  It is like some of the Democrats counted their chickens before they were hatched and now have egg on their faces.”
The city and county of Cullman kicked off their three year celebration this afternoon of Alabama's bicentennial.  The Wallace State Jazz Band and the students from West Elementary did a great job.
NA

President Trump called me to the Oval Office this morning to discuss the American Healthcare Act, because of his understanding that I could not support the current language of the bill.  He listened to my concerns about how it would impact older Alabamians and the poor in our state. I reminded him that he received overwhelming support from Alabama’s voters. The President looked me in the eye and said, "These are my people and I will not let them down. We will fix this for them."  I also asked the President point blank if this House bill was the one that he supported. He told me he supports it "one thousand percent." After receiving the President’s word that these concerns will be addressed, I changed my vote to yes. These changes will be made to the bill before it is voted on.

The 4th Congressional District Art Competition is now underway with the awards ceremony on April 17th in Guntersville.  High school students from across the district are eligible, including home schooled students.

It was great to join President Trump and my Congressional colleagues as the NASA budget was signed into law.  This means a lot to North Alabama, but also to our country as a whole.  #LetsMakeNASAGreatAgain
Here is video of President Trump signing the NASA bill in the Oval Office today.
NA

Today marks the 100th Anniversary of America's entry into World War 1.  During the next two years, more than 100,000 Americans would give their lives in service to our cause.  On this anniversary, we remember their sacrifice.
I fully support President Trump's missile strike against Syria. The actions of the Syrian regime are deplorable and unacceptable.
"He arose! He arose!  Hallelujah, Christ arose!"  Happy Easter from my family to yours.

This morning we had the annual 4th Congressional District Art Competition.  This year at the beautiful Guntersville Museum and Cultural Center.  Here is a video from this morning's event, along with a list of winners.  A special congratulations to Maggie Bachman of Guntersville High School who won Best of Show.  The People's Choice Award portion of the competition will be posted here on my page Tuesday afternoon.

It's time once again for the People's Choice Award competition as part of the 4th District Art Competition.  Starting now, and running through 5pm on Friday, April 21st, the artwork with the most likes will be the winner.  Important note:  We will only count the traditional/original Facebook like.  The other emojis like the smiley face will NOT be counted.   Thank you and good luck students!

Congratulations to Brenda Sachez - Guntersville High School, for winning our 2017 People's Choice Award.  Her piece received more than 400 votes.   She will be getting a trophy delivered to school very soon.
Thanks to everyone who made the April 2017 recess so productive.

It's hard to believe, but Sunday my daughter Mary Elliott turned 18. Her mom and I are very proud that one of the first things she wanted to do was to get online at the Alabama Secretary of State  John Merrill and register to become an Alabama voter!

Today we remember the lives lost six-years-ago in one of the largest tornado outbreaks in history.  This memorial in Rainsville honors the lives of the more than 30 killed in DeKalb County, but also reflects the sentiments we have for all the 200+ people who died across our state.
Our memorial video we made for last year's tornado anniversary.

I want to thank everyone for the calls, emails and encouragement over the past week to run for the United States Senate.  At this time, I believe my attention is better focused elsewhere.  As we have seen this week in Washington, there is a lot of work to do to implement the policies of President Trump.  Right now, the best way for me to help Alabama, our nation and President Trump, is from my position in the House of Representatives representing Alabama’s 4th Congressional District.

It was great to be in Lawrence County on Saturday to attend the dedication of the new entrance signs at the General Joe Wheeler home known as Pond Spring.  I encourage you to visit this historic treasure.

It was an honor once again this year to participate in the annual reading of the Bible from Genesis to Revelation in front of the U.S. Capitol Building.  People from all walks of life join in this effort every year leading up to the National Day of Prayer.

We had a great tour this morning with the owners of Exxel Outdoors' facility in Haleyville, along with representatives from Walmart.  Exxel makes 2 million sleeping bags per year.  It's a great made in America product sold in all 50 states.

I was very sad to learn of the passing of Radford Carter, better known to most as Radford C. from 95.9 radio in Guntersville.  He hosted the Cabin on the Hill gospel program on the station for decades, along with his wife Ruby D.   The clip below from YouTube shows you his style, that is rare to find on radio anymore.  My condolences to his family.

This is National Police Week where we honor our current law enforcement officers and those who have given their lives in the line of duty.  Here is a video we made last year to honor the men and women who serve across the 4th District.

This Memorial Day Weekend, please take time to remember that this holiday is about so much more than the "unofficial start to summer" that it has been transformed into.  It's about those who paid the price for your freedom with their very lives.

The storms that moved through North Alabama Saturday night into Sunday morning caused widespread tree damage. Our home had a large tree fall on it. We were not at home at the time.  The house has significant damage but we are blessed no one was hurt. This is a good example of why you have to stay weather aware even for things other than a tornado warning.

Below is my statement on the testimony today of former FBI Director James Comey. I think the most important detail of the testimony is that Comey said clearly and publicly, that President Trump is not under investigation.
The annual Lake Guntersville Fireworks Show over Browns Creek.

Friday, Representative Johnny Mack Morrow and I, had the privilege to honor two notable people from Franklin County with highways named for them.  Former Red Bay Mayor David Morrow and someone who is known across the country, singer Tammy Wynette.
I had the privilege of stopping by and speaking to 4th District students who are participating in the National Rural Electric Association Youth Tour in Washington this week.
Please join me in praying for my colleagues and Capitol Police.  This is a very tragic and sad situation.   Also, thank you to those who have checked on me this morning.   My staff and I are fine.
NA

While it was fun being at tonight's Congressional Baseball game with my family, our friend Steve Scalise was deeply missed. I hope you will continue to keep him, his family, and everyone impacted by Wednesday's shooting in your prayers.
NA

What a great honor it is to be at the deployment ceremony of the 115th Expeditionary Signal Battalion. Please keep the  men and women of the 115th and their families in your prayers during the next year as they serve in the Middle East.
My family and I had a great time visiting the new Bolta, U.S. facility in Tuscaloosa Friday.  This factory will produce parts for Volkswagen and Mercedes.  Big Al also seemed to enjoy himself.

I think Jeff Sessions is doing an excellent job as our nation’s Attorney General.  In his six months on the job, he has done more to uphold our nation’s laws and keep communities safe than the previous Administration did in eight years. He is a person of tremendous character and integrity.  He has my full support.

My son Robert Hayes and I had a great tour of Tiffin Motorhomes in Winfield. Tiffin is one of the wonderful employers in the 4th District. It was great meeting with Mayor Price, plant manager Bobby White and everyone at Tiffin.
I hope you get a chance to enjoy today's eclipse!
The folks at the Cullman Caring for Kids Food Bank across from our Cullman office are having an eclipse party.   Their party is complete with Sunny D and Moon Pies!

I met with constituents and local leaders this morning at the L'Rancho in Arab.  I also stopped by to speak to the Arab radio legend Archie Anderson at WRAB.  Thanks so much to Wes Kitchens and everyone at the Arab Chamber of Commerce for setting up today's event.
Thanks for the warm welcome from everyone at the Boaz Senior Center.  Robert Hayes and I also had fun visiting the Pathfinder symposium in Huntsville.
The beautiful Cullman County Courthouse on a Fall like day in Alabama.    Cullman Chamber
The new city hall in Hamilton looks great.
Here is a video we made last year, but it still reflects the view of so many of us.   The "Most Wonderful Time of the Year" is back!  I hope you enjoy the season.
Here are some photos from last week's visit to the Dynetics event in Cordova and my visit to Camp McDowell.
It was a dark day on a clear September morning 16 years ago.  Let's never forget those who died, those who lost loved ones and those who sacrificed unselfishly for our country.

What a blessing it was to meet Kruz and Paizlee today in the Shoals. They both were born with a rare genetic condition. They have an amazing story. I was invited to join them today as the Make-A-Wish Foundation announced they are sending Kruz and Paizlee to Disney World.  You can read more about them and learn how to help at kruznforakurefoundation.com
I enjoyed helping with the groundbreaking for the 51st Habitat for Humanity home in Etowah County. This one is being built in Glencoe.

It was such an honor to accompany my friend, Vice President Mike Pence, on his visit to Redstone Arsenal and the Marshall Space Flight Center.  The Vice President got to talk to the astronauts aboard the International Space Station.  He also got an update on the Space Launch System, which will return Americans to space aboard our own vehicle for the first time since the Space Shuttle program ended in 2011.
What a great moment to be on the House floor.  Steve's return is a miracle from God.  Welcome back my friend.

Today is National Farmers Day.   This old barn in the Ballplay Community of Etowah County reminds us of the importance farmers have always had in our daily lives and the role they will play in the future.
NA

In my office there is a painting by T.H. Matteson called "The First Prayer in Congress."  It commemorates and documents the fact that Congress has always opened each day's session with prayer. Today, the U.S. District Court affirmed this practice and struck down a challenge by an atheist that it was unconstitutional.  I applaud this decision. The bipartisan practice of opening each day with an acknowledgement of God will continue, as it has for more than two centuries.

I was very sad to learn of the passing of my friend and predecessor, former Alabama Congressman Jim Martin.  Voters elected Martin in 1964 as the first Republican to represent the district since the 19th Century.  The district at the time was labeled as the 7th District, but has since been split into the 4th and 5th districts.  Besides being a trailblazer in Alabama politics, Martin also started the Forever Wild program in the state, which has secured more than 22,000 acres of land for public use.  Martin was also a veteran of World War 2.  He was 99.

The tax bill released today is a good start, as it refocuses our tax code on today’s economy. Our current system was put in place when most Americans had never heard of the internet, the only phone they had was attached to the wall at home and Bill Curry and Pat Dye were coaching at Alabama and Auburn.    It’s time for a tax code that puts working Americans first.  More than 80% of the people in the 4th District will see their tax burden drop, and to me, that is a good thing.
While we were not pulling for the same team, it was such a great experience for Steve and Jennifer Scalise, to join Caroline, Mary Elliott and me at the game yesterday.
NA
We had a great group of students from Collinsville and Fyffe visit this morning.  They are here for the Family, Career and Community Leaders of America national conference.
To those who answered their nation's call, we can never repay your sacrifice.  But we can be forever grateful for your service.  Thank you and Happy Veterans Day!
Was proud to see Exxel Outdoors from Haleyville represented at last night's Alliance for American Manufacturing event here in Washington.
Thanks to everyone at the Carroll's Creek Volunteer Fire Department for giving me a tour of their great new station.

Mary Elliott and I had a great time in Cullman today.  We saw the new telemedicine partnership between the VA and the Alabama Department of Public Health.  They will begin to see veteran patients at the Cullman County Health Department.  We also got a tour of Royal Technologies.  There is a high likelihood that your car has at least some portion of it that was made here at RT in Cullman.
From our family to yours, we hope you have a happy and blessed Thanksgiving.
Arab's annual Christmas in the Park is now open.  If you haven't been, it's a great Christmas light display and it's free. I have been to this many years and I highly recommend it.

This evening the Alabama Farmers Federation presented me with the Service to Agriculture award at their annual meeting in Montgomery.  During my time in Congress I've received my fair shared of awards, but this one stands out.  To be honored by the men and women who put food on our tables everyday is a cut above the rest.  In many ways, Alabama's 4th Congressional District is Alabama's bread basket.  Whether it's cattle farms in DeKalb County, poultry farms in Cullman County or a dairy farm in Lamar County, the 4th Congressional District, along with the rest of the farmers in this state, are feeding Alabama and America.  It's an honor to serve you in Congress.  Thank you for this great honor.
It is snowing in Cullman.  Here is some video from outside our Cullman office this morning.  Stay safe and I hope you have your bread and milk!
I want to thank Vice President Mike Pence for joining us at the Capitol today to discuss issues of faith and freedom in America and around the world.

I'm very sorry to hear that my colleague and my friend, Congressman Mo Brooks, has been diagnosed with prostate cancer.  I hope you will join me in praying for him, his family and for a speedy and complete recovery.

Today is Alabama's 198th Birthday.  The Library of Congress has put together some great articles about our great state and you'll find them by clicking the link below.  My favorite is the section on the historic maps of Alabama.
NA

Santa Claus has been spotted in the sky at our house in Haleyville and across the 4th District.   From my family to yours, I hope you have a very Merry Christmas.  And as this song says, we should "give thanks to the Lord above" for sending us his son.

This afternoon I voted to give you back more of your money.  Far too many of the people in Washington believe that everything you earn belongs, not to you, but to the government.  Those people are wrong.  It is your money and you should be able to keep more of it.  When I first posted about this bill last month, many of you expressed concern about medical deductions.  We listened to your concerns and those deductions were returned to the bill.  The child tax credit has also been expanded.  More than 80% of the people in the 4th District will receive a tax cut and that is a good thing. This bill also lowers the corporate tax rate, so companies are no longer penalized for keeping their businesses and jobs in the USA. Our 20th Century Tax Code desperately needed updating.  This bill achieves that goal.
NA

It has become a tradition for us to stop by the home of Sara Harris in Arab. She celebrates Christmas in a unique way each year in order to teach her grandchildren how the birth of Christ is recognized by Christians around the world.
